instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi all.
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with no signs of life.
No obvious signs of any water, or other, damage.
No sign of heat.

Only has 5v on either USBC port.
Tried with another USBC port cable, and another known good genuine AC adapter.

F7000 0.02v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.56v
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 5.12v on pins 1 - 4.

Diode mode to ground with red probe connected to ground:
F7000 1 (1824 ohms in resistance mode).
L6960 491
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> 613

Any suggestions greatly appreciated, once again.
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Test <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with known good battery connected.
Keep audio flex disconnected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hello 2informaticos.
Thanks, once again, for your help.
Same voltage (0.56v) with or without customer's battery connected.
Unfortunately, I do not have an known good battery.
I did however try another battery from another two  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> chassis, but I do not know the state of either of them.
With both the voltage was also 0.56v.
While I assume that all three aren't problematic, I have ordered a new battery in just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
F7000 is not connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>!
Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi again 2informaticos.
I am aware F7000 is not connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. 

I received a new battery from a supplier today.
I'm sure its not a genuine, but we rarely have any issue with them.

Using the new battery, we had the same voltage (0.56v)
This is all with the just the logic board and the battery connected, with everything else disconnected.

Diode mode to ground with red to ground and black on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> measures 185.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: You should check the other way too (black at ground) and compare values with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi again.
I found a dodgy capacitor on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
It wasn't a complete short, but was getting hot when I injected a low voltage.
With it removed, the system boots and operates fine.
Thank you for your advice and help, once again, I appreciate it.
